awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ATD: Advanced Quickest Multidecision Change Detection-Classification Methods for Threat Assessment in Distributed Sensing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goal of this project is to develop the next generation of mathematical and statistical algorithms and methodologies in sensor systems for the detection of chemical and biological materials based on advanced quickest change detection and classification methods. To this end,  the next generation of the quickest joint change detection and classification methods will be developed that are optimal or nearly optimal in a variety of scenarios.  Specifically,  a general theory of multidecision quickest change detection and classification for non-i.i.d. stochastic models will be developed. Developing this general theory requires novel probabilistic methods for both designing effective quickest change detection-classification strategies as well as analyzing their performance. Furthermore, the general theory will be extended to the distributed sensor setting. In particular, novel techniques for adaptive sampling at the sensors will be explored, change process detection methods will be developed for settings where the change might occur at different times at the various sensors, and techniques for controlling the sensing process to make it energy-efficient will be designed. 
 
It is expected that the proposed theoretical advances in change detection and classification will have a strong practical impact on future systems that are built for the purposes of detecting and predicting chemical, biological and related threats using large sensor networks.  Conversely the engineering insights gained from working on this important problem will  lead to significant developments in the underlying  statistical theory of quickest change detection and classification. Advances in this theory couldpotentially have an impact on a broad spectrum of applications from qualitycontrol engineering to econometrics.

por.por_cntn:
As stated in the call for proposals, an important component of NSF program12-502 is “to develop the next generation of mathematical and statistical algorithms and methodologies in sensor systems for the detection of chemical and biological materials.” Our overarching goal in the project was to address this challenging task by developing advanced quickest change detection and classification methods for distributed sensor networks. In particular, novel techniques for adaptive sampling at the sensors were explored,  techniques for controlling the sensing process to make it energy-efficient were designed, and applications to power grid monitoring were explored.

Research activities have included: (1) data-efficient quickest change detection in minimax settings; (2) data-efficient minimax quickest change detection with unknown post-change distribution; (3) data-efficient quickest change detection in sensor networks; (4) data-efficient minimax quickest change detection in decentralized systems; and (5) quickest change detection and identification of line outages in power systems.

Educational activities have included: (1) conference papers and presentations on the above research topics; (2) invited presentations on these topics at the 2015 Applied Stochastic Models and Data Analysis (ASMDA) conference in Athens, Greece, the 2013 International Workshop on Sequential Methodologies (IWSM), Athens, GA, the 2013, 2014, and 2015 workshops on Information Theory and Applications (ITA), San Diego, CA, Boston University, University of Maryland, UC Davis, Georgia Tech, University of Florida, and Texas A&M University; (3) development of course material on quickest change detection for ECE 561, Detection and Estimation Theory, at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign; and (4) presentations on "Data-Efficient Quickest Change Detection" at the 2012 DTRA/NSF/NGA Algorithm Workshop, and on “Data-Efficient Quickest Change Detection with Composite Post-Change Distribution” at the 2015 DTRA/NSF/NGA Algorithm Workshop.

Collaboration have included: (1) PIs Tartakovsky and Veeravalli collaborated on the problem of data-efficient quickest change detection procedures for distributed sensor and multi-channel systems; (2) PIs Tartakovsky and Veeravalli organized invited sessions on topics related to the proposal at the International Workshop on Sequential Methodologies (IWSM), Athens, GA; and (3) PI Tartakovsky served on Veeravalli’s Ph.D. student’s thesis committee.

This project provided a solid foundation for extensive training of graduate students participating in the research. This project requires and calls for a unique combination of high-level statistical/probabilistic methods with understanding of functioning of  sensor networks such as those used in monitoring the power grid. More specifically, graduate students Taposh Banerjee and Georgios Rovatsos have worked on this project at UIUC. The project has provided a unique opportunity to advance the state-of-the-art of sequential hypothesis testing and quickest change detection procedures. They have learned new mathematical techniques for analyses of optimality and performance of hypothesis tests and quickest change detection procedures. They have also been trained on efficient numerical methods for performance evaluation.

Novel data-efficient/energy-efficient quickest change detection procedures have been developed in the project in both Bayesian and minimax settings and for distributed sensor networks (including those used to monitor the power grid). Our problem formulations have started a new direction of research in the area of quickest change detection, and there have been a number of researchers in the field who have been following up on our results. The developed methods and algorithms are important not just in the area of automatic threat detection to which this project is targeted, but in the related areas of theoretical and applied statistics, applied probability, engineering, and computer science. The usefulness of the developed quickest detection methods in the area of power grid monitoring has been demonstrated.
